The additional travel distance in kilometers required for vehicles to bypass the bridge if it is closed or restricted, representing network redundancy and detour severity.
The number of years that have elapsed since the bridge was originally constructed, representing its structural age and cumulative exposure to loading and environmental effects.
The total number of traffic lanes carried directly on the bridge deck, representing its vehicular capacity and functional role in the roadway system.
The total number of traffic lanes that pass beneath the bridge, representing the scale and complexity of the facility or corridor being crossed.
The average number of vehicles that cross the bridge per day under typical conditions, representing traffic demand and cumulative loading.
The clear width of the roadway approaching the bridge, measured perpendicular to traffic flow, representing how traffic transitions onto the structure.
The skew angle between the bridge alignment and the feature it crosses, representing how obliquely the structure intersects the roadway, waterway, or obstacle below.
The number of spans that make up the main structural unit of the bridge, representing how the primary load-carrying system is segmented.
The number of spans in the approach portions of the bridge, representing how the structure transitions from the main unit to the adjacent roadway.
The length of the longest individual span within the bridge, representing the maximum unsupported distance and associated structural demand.
The total length of the bridge measured from end to end, including main and approach spans, representing the overall longitudinal extent of the structure.
The width of the curb, sidewalk, or shoulder on the left side of the bridge, representing lateral separation or pedestrian accommodation.
The width of the curb, sidewalk, or shoulder on the right side of the bridge, representing lateral separation or pedestrian accommodation.
The clear roadway width available for vehicles on the bridge deck measured between curbs or barriers, representing usable traffic width.
The total out-to-out width of the bridge deck, including traffic lanes, shoulders, curbs, and barriers, representing the full structural width.
The minimum horizontal clearance available beneath the bridge on the right side, representing spatial constraints for traffic or features passing below.
The minimum horizontal clearance available beneath the bridge on the left side, representing spatial constraints for traffic or features passing below.
The number of years that have elapsed since the bridgeâ€™s most recent routine inspection, representing the recency of condition information.
The scheduled interval between routine inspections expressed in months, representing the inspection frequency applied to the bridge.
The number of years that have elapsed since the bridge was last reconstructed or substantially rehabilitated, representing the recency of major renewal work.
The percentage of average daily traffic composed of trucks, representing the intensity of heavy vehicle loading on the structure.
The projected average daily traffic expected to cross the bridge in the future, representing anticipated demand growth and long-term usage.
The total surface area of the bridge deck, representing the extent of the riding surface exposed to traffic loads and environmental conditions.
